LIMITATION IN COST-OF-LIVING ADJUSTMENTS FOR CERTAIN RETIREMENT SYSTEMS. Limitation in cost-of-living adjustments for certain retirement systems includes a reduction in increases applied to higher primary insurance amounts under Social Security Act. This involves multiplying specified amounts by an applicable increase percentage for adjustments. The increase in primary insurance amounts under the Social Security Act is determined by multiplying specified amounts by an applicable increase percentage, identifying the 30th percentile amount, and adjusting the primary insurance amount accordingly. Any non-multiple of $0.10 is rounded down, and any increase is subject to specific adjustments. The Social Security Act determines increases in primary insurance amounts by multiplying specified amounts by an applicable percentage. Any non-multiple of $0.10 is rounded down, and adjustments are made for increases. Amendments are made to maintain current levels of cost-of-living adjustments under other programs. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act to determine increases in benefit amounts under title II, supplementary medical insurance, and certain veteran's benefits. The changes involve using the applicable increase percentage to calculate benefit amounts for the month of December preceding the year of the promulgation. Amendments to title 38, United States Code, involve using the applicable increase percentage to calculate benefit amounts under the Social Security Act. Amendments to title 38, United States Code involve calculating benefit amounts under the Social Security Act using specific increase percentages and making adjustments to limitations on benefits and contributions under qualified plans in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The subsection in effect in December 1978 and amendments made by the COLA Limitation Act of 1995 regulate the application of adjustments to the Civil Service Retirement System. An annuity increase is limited by specific percentages under this section. An annuity increase under the Federal Employees Retirement System is determined by multiplying each annuity by a percentage increase and finding the 30th percentile increase amount. Any amount not a multiple of $0.10 is decreased to the next lower multiple. An annuity increase under the Federal Employees Retirement System is limited to the lesser of the amount that would apply without certain provisions or the amount determined under specific criteria. The increase is calculated by multiplying each annuity by a percentage increase and finding the 30th percentile increase amount, which is then adjusted to the nearest lower multiple of $0.10. The retired pay of a member or former member under Section 1401a(b) of title 10, United States Code, is subject to an overall limitation on increases from adjustments, ensuring it does not exceed a certain amount. The retired pay of a member under Section 1401a(b) of title 10, United States Code is limited to prevent exceeding a certain amount. The increase in retired pay is calculated based on specific percentages and amounts determined in the preceding paragraphs. The retired pay increase amount is adjusted based on specific percentages and amounts, subject to certain limitations described in Section 1401a(b)(5) of title 10, United States Code. Amendments are made to various sections to reflect these changes. The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to adjustments effective with months after the date of the enactment of this Act, subject to specific limitations described in Section 1401a(b)(5) of title 10, United States Code.
